FieldValue.Value: Adolescent health risk behavior assessment.
Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium. Adolescent health risk behavior assessment. Southfield (MI): Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium; 2012 Sep. 1 p.

This is the current release of the guideline.

This guideline was republished in September 2013.

ICD9CM: Alcohol abuse, unspecified (305.00); Anxiety state, unspecified (300.00); Eating disorder, unspecified (307.50); Human immunodeficiency virus [HIV] disease (042); Major depressive affective disorder, recurrent episode, unspecified (296.30); Major depressive affective disorder, single episode, unspecified (296.20); Other, mixed, or unspecified drug abuse, unspecified (305.90); Suicidal ideation (V62.84); Tobacco use disorder (305.1); Venereal disease, unspecified (099.9)

MSH: Adolescent Health Services ; Alcohol-Related Disorders ; Anxiety ; Counseling ; Depression ; Eating Disorders ; HIV Infections ; Physician-Patient Relations ; Pregnancy in Adolescence ; Pregnancy, Unplanned ; Psychiatric Status Rating Scales ; Referral and Consultation ; Risk Assessment ; Risk Reduction Behavior ; Self-Injurious Behavior ; Sexually Transmitted Diseases ; Suicidal Ideation ; Tobacco Use Disorder ; Trust ; Violence ; Wounds and Injuries

MTH: Alcohol abuse ; Anxiety ; Anxiety state ; Counseling ; Drug abuse screening test ; Eating Disorders ; Feeling suicidal (finding) ; HIV Infections ; HIV screen ; Mental Depression ; Pregnancy in Adolescence ; Rapport ; Risk Assessment ; Screening for venereal disease ; Self-Injurious Behavior ; Sexually Transmitted Diseases ; Tobacco Use Disorder ; Trust (Social Behavior) ; Unplanned pregnancy ; Wounds and Injuries
PDQ: tobacco use disorder

SNOMEDCT_US: Alcohol abuse (15167005); Alcohol consumption screening (171208001); Alcohol-induced organic mental disorder (29212009); Anxiety (48694002); Anxiety state (198288003); Counseling (129441002); Counseling (409063005); Drug abuse screening test (273426006); Eating disorder (72366004); Empowerment (225347007); Feeling suicidal (225457007); Feeling suicidal (6471006); HIV screening (171121004); Human immunodeficiency virus infection (86406008); Mental health screening assessment (410229003); Recurrent major depressive episodes (268621008); Recurrent major depressive episodes (66344007); Risk assessment (225338004); Self-harm (248061004); Self-injurious behavior (248062006); Sexually transmitted infectious disease (8098009); Single major depressive episode (268620009); Single major depressive episode (36923009); Suicide risk assessment (225337009); Teenage pregnancy (237240001); Unplanned pregnancy (83074005); Venereal disease screening (171128005)

Adolescent health risk behavior, including:

  • Unintentional injuries/violence
  • Depression, anxiety, self-harm, suicidal ideation/behaviors
  • Tobacco, alcohol, and other drug use
  • Unintended pregnancy, sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
  • Dietary behaviors
Risk Assessment
Emergency Medicine
Family Practice
Obstetrics and Gynecology
Preventive Medicine
Advanced Practice Nurses
Health Plans
Physician Assistants

• To achieve significant, measurable improvements in the assessment of adolescent health risk behavior through the development and implementation of common evidence-based clinical practice guidelines
  • To design concise guidelines that are focused on key assessment components of adolescent health risk behavior to improve outcomes

• Adolescent males and females 11 to 20 years of age, accessing healthcare in a variety of settings: primary care clinics, school-based health centers, sexually transmitted infection (STI) clinics, mental health clinics, emergency centers
  • Patients at risk
  • Parents, guardians, or other trusted adults

1. Create an environment that builds trust and rapport
  2. Support with referrals and resources
  3. Use a developmentally appropriate screening tool to identify risk of the leading causes of adolescent morbidity and mortality
  4. Engage interventions to reduce risk
    • Assess risks and adapt counseling techniques
    • Assist in developing a risk reduction plan
    • Arrange follow-up testing, counseling, or referrals
  5. Empower adolescents to make healthy decisions
Adolescent morbidity and mortality

Field.Name: Methods Used to Collect/Select the Evidence

FieldValue.Value: Searches of Electronic Databases

Field.Name: Description of Methods Used to Collect/Select the Evidence

FieldValue.Value: The Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) health care analyst conducts a search of current literature in support of the guideline topic. Computer database searches are used to identify published studies, existing protocols and/or national guidelines on the selected topic developed by organizations such as the American Diabetes Association, American Heart Association, American Academy of Pediatrics, etc. If available, clinical practice guidelines from participating MQIC health plans and Michigan health systems are also used to develop a framework for the new guideline.
Not stated

Field.Name: Methods Used to Assess the Quality and Strength of the Evidence

FieldValue.Value: Weighting According to a Rating Scheme (Scheme Given)

Field.Name: Rating Scheme for the Strength of the Evidence

FieldValue.Value:
Levels of Evidence for the Most Significant Recommendations

  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Controlled trials, no randomization
  3. Observational studies
  4. Opinion of expert panel

Field.Name: Methods Used to Analyze the Evidence
Description of the Methods Used to Analyze the Evidence

FieldValue.Value: Not stated

Field.Name: Methods Used to Formulate the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: Expert Consensus

Field.Name: Description of Methods Used to Formulate the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value:
Using information obtained from literature searches and available health plan guidelines on the designated topic, the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) health care analyst prepares a draft guideline to be reviewed by the Medical Directors' Committee at one of their scheduled meetings. Priority is given to recommendations with [A] and [B] levels of evidence (see the "Rating Scheme for the Strength of the Evidence" field).

The initial draft guideline is reviewed, evaluated, and revised by the committee resulting in draft two of the guideline. Additionally, the Michigan Academy of Family Physicians participates in guideline development at the onset of the process and throughout the guideline development procedure. The MQIC guideline feedback form and draft two of the guideline are distributed to the medical directors, as well as the MQIC measurement and implementation group members, for review and comments. Feedback from members is collected by the MQIC health care analyst and prepared for review by the Medical Directors' Committee at their next scheduled meeting. The review, evaluation, and revision process with several iterations of the guideline may be repeated over several meetings before consensus is reached on a final draft guideline.

Field.Name: Rating Scheme for the Strength of the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: Not applicable
A formal cost analysis was not performed and published cost analyses were not reviewed.
External Peer Review
Internal Peer Review

Field.Name: Description of Method of Guideline Validation

FieldValue.Value:
When consensus is reached on the final draft guideline, the Medical Directors approve the guideline for external distribution to practitioners with review and comments requested via the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) health plans (health care analyst distributes final draft to Medical Directors' Committee, measurement and implementation groups to solicit feedback).

The MQIC health care analyst also forwards the approved guideline draft to appropriate state medical specialty societies and physicians with expertise in the related field for their input. After all feedback is received from external reviews, it is presented for discussion at the next scheduled committee meeting. Based on feedback, subsequent guideline review, evaluation, and revision may be required prior to final guideline approval.

The MQIC Medical Directors approved this guideline in September 2012.

Adolescent Males and Females 11 to 20 Years of Age, accessing healthcare in a variety of settings: Primary Care Clinics, School-Based Health Centers, Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) Clinics, Mental Health Clinics, Emergency Centers

ADAPT: Create an environment that builds trust and rapport with adolescent population

Ask questions in a way that establishes trust through dialogue and body language.

  • Explain confidentiality to youth and parent before assessment is completed.
  • Ensure separate and private space for survey completion and during visit.
  • Train health professionals in effective counseling strategies such as motivational interviewing.
  • Ensure sensitivity to cultural and religious beliefs, sexual orientation and gender identity with every patient.

SUPPORT: Identify developmentally appropriate referrals and resources for at-risk patients in your community

  • Identify national, state, and local resources (e.g., Local 211 http://www.211.org/) and compile a list of community resources for use with families and patients.
  • Identify school support (e.g., school mental health providers).

SCREEN: Use a developmentally appropriate screening tool to identify risk in your adolescent patient

This tool should address the domains of risk identified by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) as the leading causes of adolescent morbidity and mortality.

Existing tools that include assessment of all domains:

  • Adolescent Health Review (AHR)
  • Bright Futures (pre-visit and supplemental questionnaires)
  • Rapid Assessment for Adolescent Preventive Services (RAAPS)

At least annually, use a brief, validated risk screening tool in all health care settings in which adolescents present for care, addressing the following categories:

  1. Unintentional injuries/violence - weapons, helmet and seat belt use, driving when distracted, bullying, abuse
  2. Mental health - depression, anxiety, self-harm, suicidal ideation/behaviors
  3. Tobacco use - cigarettes, other forms of tobacco
  4. Alcohol and other drugs - alcohol, marijuana, prescription/non-prescription drug use, inhalants, other drugs, use prior to sex, driving under influence
  5. Sexual behaviors contributing to unintended pregnancy, STIs and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) - sexual activity/involvement, sexual orientation, past pregnancy and STI, contraception use, and safer sex practices
  6. Dietary behaviors - soda intake, fruits/vegetables, dieting behaviors, fast/junk food intake
  7. Physical activity - exercise 60 minutes 3 or more days/week, screen time <2 hours/day.
  8. Protective factors - supportive adult, future goals, school/community connectedness, peer influence

Patients at Risk

ENGAGE: Identify evidence based interventions to reduce risk

Assess and discuss:

  • Patient's risks; adapt counseling techniques based on patient readiness to make behavior changes
  • Patient's strengths; elicit strengths through discussion
  • Elicit implications, consequences, and adverse outcomes associated with risk in relationship to life goals

Assist patients in reducing their risk(s) by:

  • Developing a risk reduction and/or safety plan based on patient's goals & readiness to make behavior changes
  • Encouraging safer choices and behaviors and discussing multiple options to reduce risky behaviors (e.g., How can we work together to keep you safe and healthy?)
  • Offering prescriptions and developmentally appropriate information and resources when needed

Arrange follow-up testing, counseling, or referrals

Frequency of follow up is based upon risk behaviors identified and risk reduction plans created.

  • Minors may access confidential services without parental consent.
  • Ensure follow up that protects the patient's privacy and confidentiality. Obtain a safe and confidential phone number or other contact information from adolescent.
  • Discuss and determine resources for social and emotional support.
  • Refer to a primary care provider, family planning clinic, local health department, dietitian, mental health provider, or substance abuse treatment center when needed.

Parents, Guardians or Other Trusted Adults

EMPOWER:

Converse with patient and parent in a way that models being the patient's advocate for making healthy decisions:

  • It is good that you are both here. It can be very helpful to have an adult to talk with about these important decisions.
  • I see that taking care of your health is important to you.
  • Making decisions to take care of yourself is not always easy.
  • I am glad that you have support for making healthy decisions.

Definitions:

Levels of Evidence for the Most Significant Recommendations

  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Controlled trials, no randomization
  3. Observational studies
  4. Opinion of expert panel
None provided

Field.Name: Type of Evidence Supporting the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value:
The type of supporting evidence is not specifically stated for each recommendation.

This guideline is based on several sources, including the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. Guide to Clinical Preventive Services, 2010-2011; American Medical Association. Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services (GAPS) Recommendations Monograph, 1997; and Committee on Adolescence. Achieving Quality Health Services for Adolescents. Pediatrics 2008;121 (6):1263-1270.

Section.Name: Benefits/Harms of Implementing the Guideline Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: Through a collaborative approach to developing and implementing common clinical practice guidelines and performance measures for the assessment of adolescent health risk behavior, Michigan health plans will achieve consistent delivery of evidence-based services and better health outcomes. This approach also will augment the practice environment for physicians by reducing the administrative burdens imposed by compliance with diverse health plan guidelines and associated requirements.
Not stated
This guideline lists core management steps. Individual patient considerations and advances in medical science may supersede or modify these recommendations.

Approved Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) guidelines are disseminated through email, U.S. mail, and websites.

The MQIC health care analyst prepares approved guidelines for distribution. Portable Document Format (PDF) versions of the guidelines are used for distribution.

The MQIC health care analyst distributes approved guidelines to MQIC membership via email.

The MQIC health care analyst submits request to website vendor to post approved guidelines to MQIC Web site (www.mqic.org).

The MQIC health care analyst completes an annual statewide postcard mailing to physicians in all areas of medicine including primary care and specialties. The postcard provides the complete list of MQIC guidelines and includes which guidelines have been recently revised, which are coming up for revision, and any new published guidelines.

The statewide mailing list is derived from the Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan (BCBSM) provider database. Approximately 95% of the state's M.D.'s and 96% of the state's D.O.'s are included in the database.

The MQIC health care analyst submits request to the National Guideline Clearinghouse (NGC) to post approved guidelines to NGC Web site (www.guideline.gov).
Chart Documentation/Checklists/Forms

Field.Name: Composition of Group That Authored the Guideline

FieldValue.Value: Physician representatives from 13 participating Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium health plans, Michigan State Medical Society, Michigan Osteopathic Association, Michigan Association of Health Plans, Michigan Department of Community Health and Michigan Peer Review Organization, and the University of Michigan Health System.

Standard disclosure is requested from all individuals participating in the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) guideline development process, including those parties who are solicited for guideline feedback (e.g., health plans, medical specialty societies). Additionally, members of the MQIC Medical Directors' Committee are asked to disclose all commercial relationships as well.

This is the current release of the guideline.

This guideline was republished in September 2013.
Electronic copies: Available in Portable Document Format (PDF) from the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium Web site.

The following are available:

  • Adolescent Health Review (AHR) questionnaire. Minnesota Department of Human Services, Available from the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium (MQIC) Web site.
  • Bright futures: guidelines for health supervision of infants, children, and adolescents. American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP). Available from the MQIC Web site.
  • Rapid Assessment for Adolescent Preventive Services (RAAPS) survey instrument. The Regents of the University of Michigan. Available from the MQIC Web site.
None available

This NGC summary was completed by ECRI Institute on January 2, 2013. The information was verified by the guideline developer on February 7, 2013. The information was republished by the guideline developer in September 2013 and updated by ECRI Institute on March 11, 2014.
This NGC summary is based on the original guideline, which may be reproduced with the citation developed by the Michigan Quality Improvement Consortium.
